thread.title: NASCAR at Charlotte: Kevin Harvick looks to put controversy behind him with win
thread.title_full: NASCAR at Charlotte: Kevin Harvick looks to put controversy behind him with win

author: customerservice@sportingnews.com (Joe Rodgers)
title: NASCAR at Charlotte: Kevin Harvick looks to put controversy behind him with win
text:
NASCAR at Charlotte: Kevin Harvick looks to put controversy behind him with win Sporting News 1 day ago customerservice@sportingnews.com (Joe Rodgers) © Provided by Sporting News The opening round in the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup is over and four drivers — Jamie McMurray, Jimmie Johnson, Paul Menard and Clint Bowyer — failed to move on to the 12-driver Contender Round, which begins Saturday night at Charlotte Motor Speedway.
AdChoices The final race of the opening round wasn't without controversy. Defending NASCAR champion Kevin Harvick needed to win or face elimination; win he did. Harvick led 355 of 400 laps at Dover, which left some questioning how the No. 4 car was so good. Eyebrows were raised after the race when some of his competitors claimed Harvick's celebratory burnout was an attempt to cover up illegal modifications made to the car .
MORE: Best images from Monster Mile at Dover | Charlotte betting preview
Harvick denied any wrongdoing. He is looking for less drama at the end of this round, which consists of races at Charlotte, Kansas and Talladega.
"I think if you can win in a first‑round situation, you can definitely put yourself in a position to get those guys on the team that mental break they need," Harvick said Tuesday at a Chase media day. "You want to do all that you can do at Charlotte and Kansas just because you don't want to lead into Talladega, as much as you can try, just for the fact that there's so much out of your hands."
The Chase standings have been reset with all 12 eligible drivers now holding 3,000 points. After the Contender Round, eight drivers will advance to the Eliminator Round before the final race at Homestead-Miami Speedway on Nov. 22.
The Xfinity Series will join the Sprint Cup at Charlotte, while the Camping World Truck Series will take a week off before returning with the other two series at Talladega on Oct. 24.
TV schedule (all times Eastern) Thursday, Oct. 8
1:30 p.m.: Sprint Cup practice, NBCSN
3 p.m.: Xfinity Series practice, NBCSN
5:30 p.m.: Xfinity Series final practice, NBCSN
7:20 p.m.: Sprint Cup qualifying, NBCSN
Friday, Oct. 9
3:30 p.m.: Sprint Cup practice, NBCSN
4:45 p.m.: Xfinity Series qualifying, NBCSN
6:30 p.m.: Sprint Cup final practice, NBCSN
8 p.m.: Xfinity Series Drive for the Cure 300 (200 laps, 300 miles), NBCSN
Saturday, Oct. 10
7 p.m.: Sprint Cup Bank of America 500 (334 laps, 501 miles), NBC
Sprint Cup: 2014 Bank of America 500 race recap Harvick dominated the race, but the the real fireworks spilled over from the track into the garage.
Brad Keselowski hit Denny Hamlin's car on the cool-down lap and the two drivers had words after the race, with Hamlin having to be restrained by his crew.
Keselowski also hit the cars of Matt Kenseth and Tony Stewart on pit road after the race, igniting a fight with Kenseth and the two teams. Kenseth chased down Keselowski and leaped at him between two haulers. The two crews scuffled and had to be pulled apart as Kenseth was restrained.
Jeff Gordon finished behind Harvick, followed by McMurray, Joey Logano, Kyle Busch and Kyle Larson.
Carl Edwards will go for the season sweep of Charlotte as will his Joe Gibbs Racing team. Hamlin won the (exhibition) All-Star race at the 1.5-mile track a week before Edwards’ victory in the rain-delayed Coca-Cola 600.
Should Edwards, Hamlin, Kyle Busch or Kenseth win, it would mark the 11th win for Joe Gibbs Racing in the past 15 Sprint Cup races.

Race statistics
Average speed of race winner: 145.346 mph.
Time of race: 3 hours, 26 minutes, 49 seconds.
Margin of victory: 0.571 seconds.
Caution flags: Eight for 39 laps.
Lead changes: 32 among 14 drivers.
Recent winners at Charlotte (fall)
2014: Harvick
2013: Keselowski
2012: Bowyer
2011: Kenseth
2010: McMurray
Recent winners at Charlotte (spring)
2015: Edwards
2014: Johnson
2013: Harvick
2012: Kahne
2011: Harvick
Top five drivers at Charlotte since September 2010 (10 races)
Harvick (three wins, nine top 10s, 5.8 average finish)
Edwards (one win, seven top 10s, 8.1 average finish)
Kenseth (one win, six top 10s, one pole, 8.9 average finish)
Hamlin (nine top 10s, one pole, 7.9 average finish)
Top five driver ratings at 1.5-mile tracks since 2013 (32 races)
Harvick, 113.7
Johnson, 105.7
Kyle Busch, 104.7
Logano, 104.5
Kenseth, 104.3
News and notes
— Charlotte Motor Speedway expanded its restart zone off Turn 4 to 180 feet in response to issues over restarts. Lines were painted on the track to avoid any confusion about where the lead driver can hit the throttle when coming to the green flag.
— Of the 113 points races run at Charlotte Motor Speedway, dating to June 1960, the winner has started in the top five 64 times. On 15 of those occasions, the winner also started from the pole.
— Team Penske’s Joey Logano and Brad Keselowski have made the Contender Round of the Chase for the second straight season.
— Hendrick Motorsports boasts a track-record 18 Charlotte victories. Johnson and Kahne will have a chance to play spoiler. The No. 48 driver owns a track-record seven victories, while Kahne ranks fourth among active drivers with four.
— If Gordon can lead 128 laps Sunday, he will become the sixth driver in Sprint Cup history to lead 25,000 laps, joining Richard Petty, Dale Earnhardt, Cale Yarborough, David Pearson and Bobby Allison.
Xfinity Series: 2015 Drive for the Cure 300 preview While the Sprint Cup has seven races remaining, the Xfinity Series has five races left on its schedule.
Regan Smith and Chase Elliott have combined to win three of the last eight races and are now both within striking distance of standings leader Chris Buescher in the points. Elliott is second in the standings, 24 points behind Buescher, and Smith is third at 36 points back.
The series is ending this season on the same five tracks on which it ended last season, Elliott (8.8) and Smith (12.0) had better average finishes at those tracks than Buescher (12.8). That may not be enough, however; Buescher has held the points lead for 19 consecutive races.
Four drivers will be pulling double duty at Charlotte, racing both Friday and Saturday: Kahne, Kyle Busch, Keselowski and Austin Dillon.
Camping World Truck Series The Truck Series will be back in action Oct. 24 at Talladega Superspeedway with the Fred’s 250 powered by Coca-Cola.
